defs.docs: A runtime implementation that runs everything on the current thread.

attributes.value: ! A runtime implementation that runs everything on the current thread.
deny(rust_2018_idioms, warnings)
allow(clippy :: type_complexity)

defs.name: Arbiter
defs.docs:
Arbiters provide an asynchronous execution environment for actors, functions
 and futures. When an Arbiter is created, it spawns a new OS thread, and
 hosts an event loop. Some Arbiter functions execute on the current thread.

attributes.value: / Arbiters provide an asynchronous execution environment for actors, functions
/ and futures. When an Arbiter is created, it spawns a new OS thread, and
/ hosts an event loop. Some Arbiter functions execute on the current thread.

defs.name: current
defs.docs:
Returns the current thread's arbiter's address. If no Arbiter is present, then this
 function will panic!

attributes.value: / Returns the current thread's arbiter's address. If no Arbiter is present, then this
/ function will panic!

defs.docs: Stop arbiter from continuing it's event loop.

defs.name: new

Spawn new thread and run event loop in spawned thread.
 Returns address of newly created arbiter.

defs.name: spawn
defs.docs:
Spawn a future on the current thread. This does not create a new Arbiter
 or Arbiter address, it is simply a helper for spawning futures on the current
 thread.

attributes.value: / Spawn a future on the current thread. This does not create a new Arbiter
/ or Arbiter address, it is simply a helper for spawning futures on the current
/ thread.

defs.name: spawn_fn
defs.docs:
Executes a future on the current thread. This does not create a new Arbiter
 or Arbiter address, it is simply a helper for executing futures on the current
 thread.

attributes.value: / Executes a future on the current thread. This does not create a new Arbiter
/ or Arbiter address, it is simply a helper for executing futures on the current
/ thread.

defs.name: send
defs.docs: Send a future to the Arbiter's thread, and spawn it.

attributes.value: / Send a future to the Arbiter's thread, and spawn it.

defs.name: exec_fn
defs.docs:
Send a function to the Arbiter's thread, and execute it. Any result from the function
 is discarded.

attributes.value: / Send a function to the Arbiter's thread, and execute it. Any result from the function
/ is discarded.

defs.name: exec
defs.value: fn <F, R> (&self, f: F) -> impl Future<Output = Result<R, Canceled>>
defs.docs:
Send a function to the Arbiter's thread. This function will be executed asynchronously.
 A future is created, and when resolved will contain the result of the function sent
 to the Arbiters thread.

attributes.value: / Send a function to the Arbiter's thread. This function will be executed asynchronously.
/ A future is created, and when resolved will contain the result of the function sent
/ to the Arbiters thread.

defs.name: Builder
defs.docs: Builder struct for a actix runtime.

attributes.value: / Builder struct for a actix runtime.
/ Either use `Builder::build` to create a system and start actors.
/ Alternatively, use `Builder::run` to start the tokio runtime and
/ run a function in its context.

defs.docs:
Sets the option 'stop_on_panic' which controls whether the System is stopped when an
 uncaught panic is thrown from a worker thread.

defs.name: Runtime
defs.docs:
Single-threaded runtime provides a way to start reactor
 and runtime on the current thread.

attributes.value: / Single-threaded runtime provides a way to start reactor
/ and runtime on the current thread.
/ See [module level][mod] documentation for more details.
/ [mod]: index.html

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Returns a new runtime initialized with default configuration values.

attributes.value: allow(clippy :: new_ret_no_self)
/ Returns a new runtime initialized with default configuration values.

defs.name: spawn
defs.docs: Spawn a future onto the single-threaded runtime.

attributes.value: / Spawn a future onto the single-threaded runtime.
/ See [module level][mod] documentation for more details.
/ [mod]: index.html
/ # Examples
/ ```rust,ignore
/ # use futures::{future, Future, Stream};
/ use actix_rt::Runtime;
/ # fn dox() {
/ // Create the runtime
/ let mut rt = Runtime::new().unwrap();
/ // Spawn a future onto the runtime
/ rt.spawn(future::lazy(|_| {
/     println!("running on the runtime");
/ # pub fn main() {}
/ # Panics
/ This function panics if the spawn fails. Failure occurs if the executor
/ is currently at capacity and is unable to spawn a new future.

defs.name: block_on
defs.docs:
Runs the provided future, blocking the current thread until the future
 completes.

attributes.value: / Runs the provided future, blocking the current thread until the future
/ completes.
/ This function can be used to synchronously block the current thread
/ until the provided `future` has resolved either successfully or with an
/ error. The result of the future is then returned from this function
/ call.
/ Note that this function will **also** execute any spawned futures on the
/ current thread, but will **not** block until these other spawned futures
/ have completed. Once the function returns, any uncompleted futures
/ remain pending in the `Runtime` instance. These futures will not run
/ until `block_on` or `run` is called again.
/ The caller is responsible for ensuring that other spawned futures
/ complete execution by calling `block_on` or `run`.
